Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission's decision to dismiss the complaint under section 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act was reasonable and procedurally fair
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of discriminatory practices found
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to demonstrate discriminatory practice
Credibility_Factor: Complaint deemed frivolous and not made in good faith
Legal_Rule: Under sections 5 to 14.1, a complaint must constitute a discriminatory practice; section 41(1)(d) allows dismissal if trivial, frivolous, vexatious, or made in bad faith
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination in non-renewal or termination of maintenance contracts
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim lacked legal merit and did not fall under prohibited grounds of discrimination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of contract termination, absence of connection to prohibited grounds of discrimination
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Public Works and Government Services Canada did not renew or terminate contracts based on race
Evidence_Type: Documentary and procedural records related to contract management
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Commission's dismissal decision
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the judicial review application
Legal_Provision: Section 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional dispute over human rights complaint
Legal_Issue: Whether the CHRC has jurisdiction to hear a sexual harassment complaint against the CSA based on a contractual relationship
Evidence_Assessment: Contractual relationship involving personal service, remuneration, and control; nature of working relationship
Decision_Outcome: CHRC has jurisdiction; judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to establish jurisdictional facts for CHRC authority
Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly assessed at this stage; preliminary jurisdictional determination
Legal_Rule: 'Employment' under CHRA includes contractual service relationships with elements of personal performance, remuneration, and control
Grounds_for_Claim: Sexual harassment during participation in a CSA-IBMP study
Outcome_on_Merits: Complaint admissible; CHRC entitled to proceed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service contract terms, nature of work performed, level of control by CSA, precedent cases (e.g., Rosin)
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, employment relationship classification
Defendant_Response: CSA argued no employer-employee relationship existed
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (contract), legal precedents, institutional policies
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn CHRC's jurisdictional decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; CHRC jurisdiction upheld
Legal_Provision: Section 2(1) of the Canadian Human Rights Act defining 'employment'
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission (CHRC), Federal Court

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Commission's decision set aside
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to accommodate disability
Improper assessment of bona fide occupational requirements
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Commission procedures
Grismer test for bona fide occupational requirements
Credibility: Supported by evidence of accommodation needs post-disclosure
Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (duty to accommodate)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient due to flawed Commission analysis

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Complaint dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to accommodate disability
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Institutional_Action: Investigation by Canadian Human Rights Commission, dismissal of complaint
Government_Body_or_Authority: Human Resources and Skills Development Canada (HRSDC), Canadian Human Rights Commission
Risk_Factor: Lack of communication of accommodation needs during employment
Credibility: No evidence that employer knew of disability or accommodation needs
Legal_Provision: Section of the Canadian Human Rights Act prohibiting discrimination based on disability
State_Protection_Adequacy: Investigation found to be thorough and decision reasonable

Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission reasonably dismissed the human rights complaint under paragraph 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of racial discrimination; termination due to misappropriation of funds
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show discriminatory basis
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss a complaint if inquiry is unwarranted or lacks jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination in termination
Outcome_on_Merits: No merit found; termination was non-discriminatory
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of misconduct (misappropriation), lack of discriminatory pattern
Legal_Framework: Human rights complaint process, federal jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Termination based on financial misconduct, not race
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission reasonably dismissed the human rights complaint under paragraph 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Employee dismissed for 'kiting' and financial misconduct; no evidence of racial motivation
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish discriminatory intent
Credibility_Factor: Consistent disciplinary treatment of similar misconduct
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss complaint if no reasonable basis or non-discriminatory grounds
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination in dismissal for financial misconduct
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim unfounded; dismissal based on legitimate cause
Key_Evidence_Considered: Pattern of employee misconduct, 'kiting' practices, equal enforcement
Legal_Framework: Human rights complaint process, federal jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Disciplinary action based on financial misconduct, not race
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Complaint dismissed due to insufficient evidence

Targeted_Group: Individual based on disability, age, race, and gender
Credibility: Complainant provided submissions; investigation deemed thorough
Legal_Provision: Section 14 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (procedural fairness)

Risk_Nature: Non-materialization of discrimination claim due to lack of evidence

Dispute_Type: Human rights discrimination based on family status and disability
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing Mr. Hicks's complaint under s. 41(1)(c) of the CHRA
Governing_Law: Canadian Human Rights Act (CHRA), ss. 3(1), 7, 10, and 41(1)(c)
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of whether there was a link between the TDRA Directive and prohibited grounds of discrimination
Decision_Outcome: Commission's dismissal found unreasonable; case remitted for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to establish prima facie discrimination
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Hicks's arguments regarding interpretation of 'family status' and jurisprudence were not adequately considered
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(c) of the CHRA, the Commission must not deal with complaints outside its jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Discrimination on the basis of family status and disability in employment
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of TDRA Directive, Mr. Hicks's personal circumstances related to family and disability
Legal_Framework: Federal human rights law, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Commission argued complaint was outside jurisdiction and lacked link to prohibited grounds
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, legal arguments, policy interpretation
Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of the complaint by the Commission
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; Commission ordered to reconsider complaint

Crimes.Application_Factor: Children’s psychological well-being and safety risks in country of origin
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, case remanded

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion under international convention
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred by failing to assess rehabilitation or current danger to the public before exclusion under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show error in Board's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – decision based on legal interpretation, not credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals who committed serious non-political crimes; rehabilitation and current danger are not relevant factors
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unlawful fettering of discretion by ignoring rehabilitation and public safety
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior U.S. convictions for assault with deadly weapon
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Febles argued he was rehabilitated and no longer a danger
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of exclusion decision and referral back to Refugee Protection Division

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 183

Crimes.Application_Facts: Febles entered Canada legally but remained beyond authorized period

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Refugee Protection Division to apply Article 1F(b)

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question on rehabilitation under Article 1F(b)

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Rehabilitation and current danger irrelevant under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Convictions accepted as proven facts

Legal_Issue: Did the officer apply the correct test for H&C application and consider all relevant evidence?
Evidence_Assessment: The officer considered risk as part of hardship but ignored financial, medical, and familial hardships. Relevant economic conditions in Nigeria and personal circumstances were overlooked.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was unreasonable due to failure to consider key evidence.
Legal_Rule: H&C applications require assessing unusual, disproportionate, or undeserved hardship.
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant's H&C application denied, leading to judicial review.
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision set aside; case referred to another officer for reconsideration with updated evidence.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Risk, financial hardship, medical hardship, familial hardship, economic conditions in Nigeria, personal circumstances
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application under Canadian immigration law
Evidence_Type: Financial, medical, familial, country condition, personal circumstances
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remanded for reconsideration

Dispute_Type: Employment dispute involving termination of employment
Legal_Issue: Whether a court can review an adjudicator's decision under the Canada Labour Code in the presence of a privative clause
Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator considered employee's length of service, nature of absence, and pattern of conduct
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator found dismissal unjust; decision upheld on judicial review
Burden_of_Proof: On the employee to demonstrate that dismissal was unjust under the Canada Labour Code
Credibility_Factor: Adjudicator assessed credibility of reasons for absence and employer's disciplinary rationale
Legal_Rule: Judicial review limited to jurisdictional errors or patently unreasonable decisions when a privative clause exists
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness standard applied due to privative clause
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized absence treated as a culminating incident leading to dismissal
Outcome_on_Merits: Dismissal deemed unjust; employee's complaint was substantiated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Length of service, history of absences, employer's disciplinary policies, context of the final absence
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, employment law, Canada Labour Code provisions on unjust dismissal
Defendant_Response: Employer justified dismissal based on unauthorized absence and prior warnings
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, employment records, testimony before adjudicator
Outcome: Adjudicator's decision upheld; judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Section of the Canada Labour Code dealing with unjust dismissal complaints
Authority: Federal Court, administrative adjudicator under the Canada Labour Code

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of expert disbursements in costs award
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment officer's evaluation of Apotex's cost claims, including expert fees and photocopy expenses
Decision_Outcome: Review allowed in part; costs award reduced by $206,411.00
Burden_of_Proof: On Merck to show error in principle or unreasonableness
Credibility_Factor: Assessment officer's discretion in evaluating reasonableness of claimed costs
Legal_Rule: Rule 414 allows review by a Federal Court judge if error in principle or unreasonable result
Grounds_for_Claim: Excessive and unsupported expert fees, particularly Dr. Langer's charges
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for Merck; reduction in costs awarded to Apotex
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dr. Langer's fee breakdown, number of experts used, photocopy expense claims
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, judicial review principles
Defendant_Response: Apotex defended the original costs award as reasonable and supported
Evidence_Type: Cost submissions, expert billing records, assessment officer's report
Outcome: Costs reduced by $206,411.00; otherwise upheld

Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister can confirm reassessments initially based on a repealed section of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Sections 152(3), 152(8), 166, and s. 74(5) (repealed) of the Income Tax Act
Procedural_Stage: Objections, confirmation of reassessments, motion under Federal Court Rule 474
Evidence_Assessment: Initial reliance on repealed s. 74(5), correction by Minister using valid sections (ss. 3 and 9)
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to show error was substantial and fundamental
Legal_Rule: Errors in assessment do not invalidate assessments unless they are substantial and fundamental; Minister may correct errors
Grounds_for_Claim: Initial reliance on a repealed statutory provision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of reassessment, applicable sections of the Income Tax Act, precedent (Belle-Isle)
Legal_Framework: Income Tax Act, Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: Argued that reliance on a repealed section invalidated the reassessment
Outcome: Reassessments confirmed as valid
Legal_Provision: ss. 152(3), 152(8), 166, 3, 9, and formerly s. 74(5) of the Income Tax Act
Authority: Minister of National Revenue, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether reasons are required when an interview is denied or when positive discretion under s. 11(3)(a) is not exercised
Governing_Law: Section 11.1 and Section 11(3) of the Immigration Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant scored 59 units, below the 60-unit threshold for an interview; even with maximum personal suitability points, fell short of 70-unit requirement
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in decision-making process
Legal_Rule: Reasons are required only when discretion is exercised, not when it is denied
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness due to lack of reasons for denying interview and not exercising positive discretion
Outcome_on_Merits: No duty to provide reasons for non-exercise of discretion; claim failed on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's point score, eligibility thresholds, officer's assessment of discretionary factors
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer considered but did not exercise positive discretion; no reasons provided
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (application forms, scoring sheet, regulatory thresholds)
Outcome: Application dismissed; counsel ordered to pay $100 costs for improper notice

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of internal flight alternative (IFA) given daughter's medical needs
Evidence_Assessment: Barriers to accessing cancer treatment in Mumbai for the applicant's daughter
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found IFA determination unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate risk, but officer must reasonably assess IFA
Credibility_Factor: Medical evidence regarding daughter’s health and treatment requirements
Legal_Rule: IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution; (2) conditions not unreasonable to seek refuge internally
Grounds_for_Claim: Specialized medical needs make Mumbai an unreasonable IFA
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on daughter’s cancer treatment needs, healthcare access in Mumbai
Legal_Framework: PRRA process, s. 97 and s. 112 of IRPA, case law on IFA
Defendant_Response: Officer asserted Mumbai was a viable IFA
Evidence_Type: Documentary medical evidence, country condition information
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted to a different officer

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark SMITH & BARNES LONDON is confusingly similar to London Drugs' trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Appeal to the Federal Court under Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Co-existing 'London' marks in clothing/housewares, limited use in retail services; differences in appearance, sound, and meaning between the marks
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; no likelihood of confusion found
Burden_of_Proof: On the opponent (London Drugs) to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Reputation of London Drugs considered, but 'London' deemed geographically descriptive and not inherently distinctive
Legal_Rule: Confusion exists if marks resemble in appearance, sound, or suggested ideas and could mislead consumers about origin
Grounds_for_Claim: Potential consumer confusion due to similarity with existing LONDON DRUGS trademarks
Outcome_on_Merits: No confusion found; marks sufficiently distinct
Key_Evidence_Considered: Appearance, sound, and meaning of the marks; duration and nature of use; sector-specific use of 'London' in trademarks
Legal_Framework: Factors: distinctiveness, use duration, nature of goods/services, trade nature, resemblance degree, and other circumstances
Defendant_Response: International Clothiers argued lack of resemblance and coexistence of similar marks
Evidence_Type: Trademark usage evidence, comparative analysis of marks
Remedy_Requested: Opposition to registration of SMITH & BARNES LONDON
Outcome: Opposition failed; appeal dismissed with costs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer erred in dismissing the claim due to lack of evidence and misunderstanding of risks under s. 96 and s. 97
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration by a different Officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to properly assess credibility of new evidence and medical reports
Legal_Provision: s. 97 IRPA (Person in need of protection)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute and family violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing threats despite cessation of land dispute pursuit
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal of new evidence without valid reasoning
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Connection to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta vs. broader persecution analysis

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats linked to familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Applicant facing credible threats from relative
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator is a Kenyan police officer; history of violence and murders linked to dispute
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of violent acts including murder attributed to perpetrator
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing and credible risk of harm or death
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized threat due to familial conflict with potential state actor involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to justify dismissal of credible evidence

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Assault arising from familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual subjected to physical violence and threats
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Involvement of state actor (police officer cousin); ongoing nature of threats
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of violent behavior including prior assaults
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized, non-state actor with state connections
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate evidence presented but not properly analyzed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer dismissed evidence without justification

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided but dismissed without proper analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supportive of PTSD and ongoing danger
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to engage with medical and documentary evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer properly assessed new evidence and state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to consider new evidence on threats and murders
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show risk, but officer must fairly assess evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Medical report supporting PTSD diagnosis ignored
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Requirement of well-founded fear or risk under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected initially, later quashed on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee protection under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection claimed but inadequately analyzed

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Land ownership dispute involving family member who is a police officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer erred in rejecting new evidence and assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to assess credibility of new threat evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to personal conflict with state-linked actor
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Involvement of police officer cousin and pattern of violence
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper dismissal of evidence and flawed legal application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for facts, correctness for legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Nexus to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta versus systemic risk analysis

Legal_Issue: Is the trademark 'The Mild One' registrable under the Trade-marks Act despite being potentially descriptive?
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence showed similar trademarks were registered; structure and disclaimer of 'MILD' contribute to distinctiveness
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court overturned the Registrar's decision
Credibility_Factor: Registrar initially rejected application; additional evidence presented on appeal
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b): prohibits clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive marks; Section 35: allows disclaimers; Section 56(1): provides right of appeal
Standard_of_Review: Statutory appeal standard under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark is distinctive as a whole despite descriptive component
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similar trademarks previously registered, disclaimer of 'MILD', overall distinctiveness
Legal_Framework: Canadian federal trademark law, Trade-marks Act
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Remedy_Requested: Registration of the trademark 'The Mild One'
Outcome: Appeal allowed; trademark registration permitted
Legal_Provision: Section 12(1)(b), Section 35, Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants can prove irreparable harm to justify a stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: Business loss and potential U.S. detention were unsubstantiated; no evidence of life-threatening harm upon return
Decision_Outcome: Motion denied, removal order to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to meet burden of proving irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Claims discredited; no credible risk found by Refugee Division and PRRA officer
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be proven, not speculative, and cannot rely solely on discredited claims
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on prior tribunal decisions and Federal Court review
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk in returning to Turkey, potential harm in the U.S.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Findings of Refugee Division and PRRA officer, lack of evidence on business loss and detention risk
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection legislation, stay of removal procedures
Outcome: Denied
Authority: Federal Court, Refugee Division, PRRA officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer's decision to deny stay of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed, but personal circumstances were relevant
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Special circumstances warranting deferral of removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider personal circumstances
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable consideration of special circumstances under s. 48(2)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Existence of special circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of familial trust and power
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk upon return to Pakistan due to stigma and potential reprisals
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Fear of social and familial retaliation
Crimes.Threat_Source: Family and societal structures in country of origin
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to reporting sexual assault
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to trigger duty to consider
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Not challenged; accepted as part of PRRA context
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible based on consistency and supporting factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal to grant stay of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Pre-removal risk assessment and stay application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess relevant personal and health risks
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate special circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Consistency of claims and supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Discretion under s. 48(2) IRPA requires consideration of all relevant factors
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider special circumstances including health and safety risks
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of applicant on procedural fairness grounds
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Relied on procedural delays and lack of subpoena

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'BEST CANADIAN MOTOR INNS & Design' is clearly descriptive under section 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Opposition before the Trade-marks Opposition Board; appeal to the Federal Court under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Design elements were considered, but dominant words found to make the mark clearly descriptive; new expert evidence on distinctiveness of design did not alter the outcome
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate registrability of the trademark
Credibility_Factor: Expert evidence submitted but not sufficient to overcome descriptiveness finding
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b) prohibits registration of clearly descriptive trademarks
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable in administrative appeals under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on confusion and descriptiveness
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark refused registration for being clearly descriptive
Key_Evidence_Considered: Textual content of the mark, design elements, expert testimony on visual impression
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative opposition and appeal process
Defendant_Response: Opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness and potential confusion
Outcome: Registrar's decision upheld; appeal dismissed with costs to Respondent

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD reasonably questioned credibility due to omissions, inconsistent travel details, questionable military documents, and delayed asylum claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative inconsistencies undermining credibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and plausibility of asylum claim
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicious military documents lacking official features

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada illegally and claimed asylum after detentions in Turkey
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues related to threats, travel, and documentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over RPD decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration for key events
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies affecting reliability

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration officials
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Truthfulness of applicant’s statements in asylum application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Multiple inconsistencies in testimony and forms; minor errors but overall reasonable finding
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative effect of inconsistencies
Application_Error: Inconsistent statements about travel and threats
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility analysis
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Plausibility and consistency of narrative

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility of draft evasion as basis for persecution claim
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Letters on draft evasion lacked security features and were deemed suspicious
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony and questionable documents
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to draft evasion and Kurdish activism
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to credibility issues
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee definition under IRPA s. 96
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed fear of imprisonment and persecution in Turkey

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's determination that adequate state protection exists in Colombia is reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board considered both favorable and conflicting evidence regarding state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to demonstrate inability or unwillingness to avail themselves of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' actions were found inconsistent with genuine fear; lack of reporting to authorities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – reasonableness standard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by FARC and insufficient state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to adequate state protection despite imperfections
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Government efforts to combat guerrilla groups, availability of protection in Bogota, applicants’ failure to report threats
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Convention refugee definition under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board emphasized existence of state mechanisms and applicant credibility issues
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court upheld the Board's decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted threats from organized armed group
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state protection programs in urban areas like Bogota
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Ongoing human rights violations by FARC but declining state control
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involving death threats and forced recruitment
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: General risk in rural areas, lower in urban centers with state presence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on refusal to comply with demands
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish lack of state protection due to unreported incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to inconsistencies and failure to seek asylum elsewhere
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ fear deemed not subjectively genuine
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Convention refugee criteria

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on intimidation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board’s finding on subjective fear and state protection
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed credibility based on lack of police reporting and alternative asylum options
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants did not meet burden to show inability to access state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report threats and bypassing U.S. asylum opportunity undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA requires both subjective and objective components
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC after refusing demands
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to sufficient state protection and credibility concerns
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of engagement with Colombian authorities, possibility of internal relocation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International and domestic refugee law standards
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board cited functional state institutions and applicant inconsistencies
Crimes.Outcome: Board’s decision upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Prior_Criminality: Applicant's involvement in a robbery (charges later withdrawn)

Violation_Type: Security clearance denial based on past criminal incident
Application_Facts: Applicant was informed of the incident and given a chance to respond
Procedural_Issue: No right to a hearing; request for specific grounds deemed unnecessary
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed

Dispute_Type: Whether the marriage was entered into in good faith or for immigration purposes
Legal_Issue: Was the marriage between Ngan Van Nguyen and Thi My Hang Nguyen genuine or primarily for immigration purposes?
Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review, upholding the IAD's decision
Credibility_Assessment: The IAD found contradictions in the applicants' testimonies
Legal_Provision: A fiancée must intend to reside permanently with the sponsor after marriage and not primarily for gaining admission to Canada
Basis_of_Claim: The applicant sponsored his fiancée's immigration after marrying her following a trip to Vietnam
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of good faith in the marriage due to inconsistent testimonies
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review following appeal to the Immigration Appeal Division
Legal_Standard: Good faith intention to establish a genuine marital relationship
Application_Factor: Timing and circumstances of the relationship and marriage
Decision_Outcome: Marriage deemed not in good faith; sponsorship application denied

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1096 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Residency_Compliance: Alleged compliance with 1095-day requirement, but disputed due to evidentiary issues
Procedural_Issue: Errors in credibility assessment, misinterpretation of evidence, lack of objective audit trail
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective 'audit trail' evidence, reliance on unverified documents
Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to factual errors by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Decision quashed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence for at least 1095 days in four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Material factual errors and insufficient justification rendered decision unreasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to threats from individuals allegedly linked to police extortion in El Salvador
Misrepresentation_Element: Omissions in IMM 5611 form, inconsistencies between forms, police reports, and oral testimony
Procedural_Issue: RPD did not allow applicant to explain discrepancies in evidence
Evidence_Used: IMM 5611 form, police reports, oral testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Discrepancies in documentation and testimony not clarified
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on omissions and inconsistencies
Outcome: Procedural unfairness found by court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective and objective fear of persecution
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility
Decision_Rationale: RPD violated procedural fairness by relying on discrepancies without giving applicant chance to respond

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa officer's refusal of temporary work permit application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer reasonably interpret and apply the Labour Market Opinion (LMO) in refusing the applicant's work permit?
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no procedural unfairness or legal error found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's qualifications were considered but found insufficient
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Labour Market Opinion, job requirements, applicant's experience documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 200(3)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant lacked three years of cooking experience as stated in the LMO
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of required cooking experience despite other qualifications
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of work experience in application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe the foreign national cannot perform the required work
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Experience requirement specified in LMO and NOC

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa officer's decision based on Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer reasonably refuse the applicant's work permit based on lack of required experience?
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no procedural unfairness or reviewable error found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s qualifications assessed but deemed inadequate for cook role
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Job details, NOC requirements, LMO, applicant's resume and experience records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant did not meet three-year cooking experience requirement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient work experience as a cook despite other qualifications
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet explicit job experience requirement
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe inability to perform the work sought
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Experience requirement confirmed by LMO and NOC

Legal_Issue: Was the duty of fairness breached by failing to disclose the substance of interviews with Faduma and Abdiqani to the Applicant?
Governing_Law: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed; no breach of fairness was found.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues due to inconsistent statements and discrepancies with relatives' accounts
Evidence_Type: Inconsistencies in the Applicant's statements, discrepancies with Faduma and Abdiqani's accounts, interview records
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant had opportunity to respond to all concerns used in decision; undisclosed information did not influence outcome
Application_Error: Failure to disclose parts of interviews, but only non-relied-upon information was withheld
Evidence_Ignored: Parts of Faduma's interview not relied upon in decision
Legal_Standard: Duty of fairness requires applicant be given opportunity to respond to concerns
Application_Factor: Credibility concerns based on inconsistencies in own statements and third-party accounts

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a false statement under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the applicant's pre-removal risk assessment (PRRA) be upheld based on new evidence or risks?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility; claim dismissed due to credibility issues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence of deteriorating country conditions and personal risk as a failed refugee with forged ID
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution and cruel treatment upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible, specific evidence showing serious risk
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient new evidence that was not reasonably available earlier
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious possibility of persecution or danger under IRPA s. 96/97
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly ignored; assessed as insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in judicial review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Changed country conditions and status as failed refugee
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of forged identity document noted but not independently prosecuted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a forged identity card
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Risk assessment upon removal to home country
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the applicant at risk of persecution or harm upon return to Sri Lanka due to possession of a forged identity card?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claimant's overall credibility undermined by prior inconsistencies and lack of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged risks related to use of forged ID and state scrutiny in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of IRPA (risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of punishment by Sri Lankan authorities for immigration document fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of concrete evidence linking forged ID to probable risk of torture or death
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Pre-removal risk assessment and judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not demonstrate that risk stemmed directly from the forged ID
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious possibility of danger under IRPA s. 97
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Generalized country condition reports without personalization
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of PRRA officer’s conclusion
Crimes.Application_Factor: Status as failed refugee and use of fraudulent documents
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; applicant must return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Authority: Canada Border Services Agency, IRB, Federal Court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Confirmed possession of forged identity card

Crimes.Violation_Type: Re-entry and removal risk after failed refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA regarding post-claim risk assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Claimant asserted worsened conditions in Sri Lanka and personal vulnerability as a returned failed refugee
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada post-refusal; subject to removal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of forged ID and credibility concerns during initial claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Availability and timeliness of new evidence for PRRA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over PRRA judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition updates, individual circumstances, PRRA submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove individualized risk beyond speculative possibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility affecting weight of new claims
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order enforceable; no protection granted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status under PRRA
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution or danger under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial change in country conditions or personal circumstances demonstrated
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), CBSA, IRB

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of citizenship judge's decision on physical presence
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed, case remitted to a different citizenship judge
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubt raised due to lack of key evidence and unexplained gaps
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Requirement of 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Respondent claimed 1,101 days of presence but failed to substantiate with reliable evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of diplomatic passport covering 9-month period
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to account for evidentiary gaps in residency proof
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence by preponderance of evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration and continuity of physical presence in Canada

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with documentary requirements for citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act – obligation to provide complete and verifiable evidence of physical presence
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent omitted diplomatic passport and had incomplete financial records
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Alleged 1,101 days of presence, but insufficiently verified
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to omission of material document
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to justify absence of critical documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by unexplained omissions
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted for reconsideration by a different citizenship judge
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application with proper evidentiary assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant bears burden of proof for meeting residency requirement
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge failed to address significant evidentiary gaps, rendering decision unreasonable

Sentencing_Issue: Pre-trial custody included in term of imprisonment

Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA
Legal_Rule: Pre-trial custody counts toward term of imprisonment
Grounds_for_Claim: IAD lacked jurisdiction due to serious criminality
Legal_Framework: IRPA s. 64(2)
Defendant_Response: Argued pre-trial custody should not count
Outcome: Deportation order upheld

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to serious criminality
Application_Facts: Ngoc Quang Nguyen sentenced to 18 months with 11 months pre-trial credit, total 29 months
Procedural_Issue: Jurisdiction to appeal based on sentence length
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction when serious criminality threshold is met
Outcome: Deportation order upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Term of imprisonment includes pre-sentence custody
Decision_Rationale: Total effective sentence exceeds two years; pre-trial custody included

Violation_Type: Failure to prove unavailability of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 96(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Family fled Mexico after alleged threats from local criminals; claimed lack of state protection; did not report incidents to police
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division (RPD) decision
Evidence_Used: Applicants' claims of criminal threats, lack of engagement with Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence showing that seeking police protection would have put them at risk; no nexus to protected grounds under s. 96
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants failed to establish credibility regarding state protection unavailability
Decision_Outcome: RPD concluded state protection was available in Mexico
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees and protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 96 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible; applicants did not meet burden of proof to show state protection unavailable

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Visa Application Denial
Legal_Provision_Violated: Personal suitability assessment under economic factors
Application_Facts: Applicant lacked savings and ignored modern bookkeeping methods; jewelry was not liquid and irrelevant
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of motivation and adaptability during interview
Evidence_Used: Lack of assets, absence of computer skills, interview responses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide proof of financial stability or technological adaptability
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found poor motivation based on lack of preparation and outdated practices
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of personal suitability including economic motivation and adaptability
Decision_Rationale: Officer validly considered lack of assets and computer skills as indicators of poor motivation and adaptability

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper application of reasonableness standard instead of de novo hearing
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility was central; new evidence of sexual assault impacted credibility findings
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on political persecution and sexual assault
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to conduct a de novo hearing on all evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied reasonableness standard instead of de novo review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: De novo review required but not conducted
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Full reassessment of original and new evidence not performed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: De novo standard for credibility when new evidence is introduced
Crimes.Application_Factor: Introduction of fresh evidence affecting credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Original dismissal upheld improperly due to incorrect standard

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration authorities
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to conduct de novo hearing upon introduction of new evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility central; new evidence of sexual assault affected assessment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection claim dismissed over credibility concerns
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: New evidence impacting credibility necessitates full re-evaluation
Crimes.Application_Error: Reviewed RPD decision for reasonableness rather than conducting de novo review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: De novo review required but not applied
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Did not reassess all evidence afresh including prior testimony
Crimes.Legal_Standard: De novo standard applies when new credibility-affecting evidence is submitted
Crimes.Application_Factor: Submission of new evidence post-RPD decision
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed based on flawed standard of review

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Exploitation through sexual assault during transit
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicants acted out of fear for safety and survival
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No indication of prior criminal involvement by applicants
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High due to cross-border illegal entry with exploitation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk to individuals due to trauma and vulnerability
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient new evidence presented to warrant re-hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence of sexual assault during smuggling
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credibility central; new evidence challenged prior findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD dismissed claim on credibility grounds; new evidence raised doubts
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – matter under administrative immigration process

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper standard of review in assessing credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal stage before Refugee Appeal Division
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: New evidence of sexual assault not fully integrated into credibility analysis
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new hearing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish basis for refugee protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Credibility was pivotal; failure to reassess undermined fairness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: RAD must conduct de novo review when new evidence affects credibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: De novo required but reasonableness incorrectly applied
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Error in law regarding standard of review and procedure
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Remanded for redetermination by new panel
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to IRB decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Government defended RAD’s application of reasonableness standard
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit and testimonial evidence of sexual assault
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and order for new hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections relevant to appeals and fresh evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to conduct de novo hearing after submission of new evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: New evidence of sexual assault introduced post-hearing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new hearing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to prove need for protection and credibility
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prior inconsistencies led to rejection; new evidence challenged this
Crimes.Legal_Rule: De novo review required when new evidence impacts credibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard improperly used over de novo
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Legal error in failing to reassess all evidence anew
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Court found legal error, ordered rehearing
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit detailing history of sexual assault
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards in immigration appeals
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister argued that RAD properly exercised discretion
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and order for new hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on appeal rights and fresh evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of the officer's decision on misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a) and s. 42
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Bashir claimed ignorance but provided no evidence to refute misrepresentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false documents for a family member
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Provision of counterfeit documents constituting misrepresentation regardless of intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of forged academic credentials in application package
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None – applicant failed to provide countervailing evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family member’s inadmissibility affecting principal applicant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence; two-year inadmissibility period

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether misrepresentation by a family member renders principal applicant inadmissible
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Bashir failed to substantiate claim of unawareness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Counterfeit educational certificates for daughter Aslam
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Derivative inadmissibility based on family member's fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Automatic inadmissibility under s. 42 when accompanying family member is inadmissible
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review initiated by sponsor Mahmood Rashid
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to verify authenticity of submitted academic documents
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision and compliance with procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No credible evidence provided in response to fairness letter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and statutory interpretation of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependence of principal applicant’s eligibility on family member’s admissibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Upholding of visa officer's refusal decision

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration document fraud in application process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Validity of refusal based on submission of counterfeit documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of ignorance not supported by evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Forged educational certificates for dependent child
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Direct submission of falsified academic records
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Presence of counterfeit documents constitutes misrepresentation per IRPA
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Administrative reasonableness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant did not present any rebuttal evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with procedural fairness and correct application of law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fake credentials in immigration sponsorship context

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Mahjoub's release can be modified to neutralize threat to national security or safety of any person
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Mahjoub has repeatedly disavowed Islamic extremism; no evidence of contact with terrorists since 2000
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Security certificate alleging ties to terrorist organizations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Length of detention, compliance with conditions, lack of new evidence, health deterioration
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether release under conditions would be injurious to national security or endanger any person
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Ministers' claims without new supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 82(5), IRPA
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in obtaining travel documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in conduct contrary to a court order
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review and modification of release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can Mr. Mahjoub be released under less stringent conditions without posing a threat?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No new threat-related activities; health issues and isolation noted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to justify continued detention
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Compliance with prior conditions and willingness to accept GPS monitoring
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for less restrictive conditions due to prolonged detention and health concerns
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and Charter considerations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Agreed to GPS and modified supervision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Threatening the security of Canada through association with terrorist groups
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged ties to Egyptian Islamic terrorist organizations
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security if released without controls
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Diminished over time due to long detention and disengagement
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Egyptian Islamic Jihad or related entities
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged involvement based on security certificate
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Classified evidence presented by CSIS; no recent corroboration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of updated intelligence to support ongoing high threat level
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible past concern but diminished current risk

Crimes.Crime_Name: Participating in activities of a terrorist group
Crimes.Application_Facts: Security certificate issued based on alleged participation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to immigration control due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of security certificate and access to evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and security
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of recent evidence demonstrating active participation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Past allegations not currently substantiated
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Threat reduced over time; conditions can mitigate residual risk
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Detention under security certificate for alleged terrorist links
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential danger if released without safeguards
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reduced due to prolonged detention and behavioral compliance
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged based on intelligence, not criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on classified intelligence; limited disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on stale intelligence without renewal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns mitigated by time and behavior
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief based on balance of probabilities

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a weapon or explosive substance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can conditions be adjusted to allow less restrictive supervision without compromising security?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of weapon possession; focus on general threat level
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Minister to justify continued strict detention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Health deterioration, social isolation, lack of live-in supervisor
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Willingness to accept GPS and restricted movement
